instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed â€“ if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after closing and opening lid
threads.message:
had some liquid damage. Some corroded caps all over the place. Replaced them all.
Lid sensors have no corrosion.
where could i measure. what could be the next step. i have no idea.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after closing and opening lid
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after closing and opening lid
threads.message: Chaged one hall effect sensor (board), since it had wierd diode mode mesurements. Now it works. thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after closing and opening lid
threads.message: Can you tell us which element on schematics (mark) did you change?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after closing and opening lid
threads.message:
He said Hall sensor (board), is external.
Left sensor connected to J5250 and right one to J5260.
